instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V43_G3H: What is PP3V43_G3H? This is a typo of PP3V42_G3H When you see PP3V43_G3H, assume they meant to type PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message:
Customer said it just went dead; board is in pretty good condition although the DCIn board was dusty.

Here's what I have so far;

PPBUS 8.19
ACOK = 3.3 to 3.7 always moving.
<SIGNAL>PP3V43_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.34

<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is going up and down 16.3v to 16.7v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: 8.19V on PPBUS means that SMC is probably not running. Is charger light going from green to orange?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: There is no light on the charger.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: SMC not running, so probably has crap under it or died.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message:
Now that I look really closely I can actually see residue up the one side of the SMC and going under it. :(

Will keep till I get a stencil for it.

Thanks Duke.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: Just some flux and heat may bring it back, do not fully reflow just let the flux cook a bit.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message:
Just did that and it fixed it. :o

I have never fixed a board by doing a "reflow bro" ever before, thought it was a myth.

Mark solved please. :)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: good job! Always try flux under it or reflow first replacing is a not so fun job lol
